{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3562441,"name":"","username":"LHACK4142","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lhack4142/{size}/196107_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-19T23:23:18.962Z","cooked":"

Our PlayingWithFusion TOF gives false positives. A graph of the measured distance against time describes this issue really well. The first half is with an actual coral in the intake detected by the TOF. The second half is just false positives.

image1176×220 2.42 KB

I could put some filters on the distance, but apparently this issue is related to lighting. I don’t want to pull up to comp and find that our filters cannot deal with that lighting.

How do you deal with this issue?

Thanks

Is the other side of the sensor polycarb/clear? Maybe use a piece of gaffers tape to provide a consistent matte surface to bounce the beam off of.

Avoid materials that are highly reflective.

Is the other side of the sensor polycarb/clear?

I’m not sure what you mean by “the other side of the sensor”. The sensor is just pointing out of our intake.
I don’t think we could put a bit of tape as you suggest, since that would block the intake. A rough diagram of the intake is below:

  O <- intake wheel
|   <- TOF
  O <- intake wheel

Rejecting positives when the standard deviation is more than 4 works for us, and I’m comfortable adjusting the threshold in comp (there’s a method in the playingwithfusion api)

Glad you found a solution that’s working for you. I just wanted to add a few comments for anyone else who stumbles into this thread.

First, these TOF sensors use a low power IR laser to measure distance. Bright/noisy light sources such as the sun, halogen, or fluorescent lights can all affect measurement accuracy. Adding glare shields or matte targets as LPryor suggested can help.

When those don’t work, it’s usually fastest to start experimenting with the sensor measurement settings. Experiment with using long, medium, and short measurement modes. Then experiment with longer sample times (see the SetRangingMode() function.

Using the reported standard of deviation ( GetRangeSigma() ) also seems to work better in marginal lighting conditions rather than just relying on the GetStatus() function. This lets you decide for yourself how much confidence you need in your distance measurements to make a controls decision.

Finally, we don’t always catch each issue in CD as they come up. Feel free to reach out to Playing With Fusion directly at TechnicalSupport@PlayingWithFusion.com and we’ll be sure to see your questions. Thanks!
